titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the J.H. McKnight and Company records 1865-1914
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by MHS staff
Finding aid revised by MHS staff, 2022
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for encoding this finding aid was provided through a grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Ellie Arguimbau with assistance by Cuadra Assoc. 2004
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS ( Describing Archives: A Content Standard 2nd Edition)

did.abstract: J.H. McKnight and Company operated as the post trader at Fort Shaw, Montana Territory, from 1870 to 1887. In 1887 Joseph McKnight moved his business to Great Falls, where it became a general mercantile firm. In 1894 the name was changed to J.H. McKnight Company, and it continued to operate under that name after McKnight's death in 1903 until its charter expired in 1914. Records (1865-1914) include interoffice, incoming, and outgoing correspondence; financial records; legal documents; and organizational materials.

bioghist.p: J.H. McKnight and Company was founded by Joseph Hempstead McKnight during the years following 1870. McKnight, originally from Dubuque, Iowa, came west in the 1860s in the company of Thomas C. Power, a business associate. Before forming his own company, McKnight worked as clerk at sutler stores at Fort Buford, at Camp Cook on the Judith River, and at Fort Benton, where he arrived in August 1866. In 1871, McKnight, assisted by the financial backing of T.C. Power, took charge of the trading post at Fort Shaw, Montana. Fort Shaw, located at Sun River Crossing twenty miles above the mouth of the Sun River, was established in 1867. An infantry post, it served as the regimental headquarters in the military department of the Territory of Montana. It was designed to protect settlers and prospectors, to prevent the invasion of Blackfeet treaty land, and to keep the route between Fort Benton and the Helena gold fields open. As the licensed post trader, J.H. McKnight and Company served the military, plus trappers, area settlers, Indian agents from the Blackfeet Agency, and the Northwest Mounted Police of Canada. In its operation, J.H. McKnight and Company was very closely connected with T.C. Power and Brother at Fort Benton, the two owners being personal friends and business allies throughout McKnight's life. The firms supplied each other, shared orders, provided transportation for commodities, and conferred on the prices and availability of goods. In 1887, McKnight sold the Fort Shaw traders' post and moved his operation to Great Falls. There, J.H. McKnight and Company served as "wholesale and retail grocers and dealers in agricultural implements, wagons, harness, and building materials," at the corner of Central Avenue and Third Street in the McKnight Block. The organization of the firm was formalized in 1894 when bylaws were adopted, stock was issued, and the name was altered to J.H. McKnight Company. Originally there were only four stockholders: T.C. Power and J.H. McKnight (499 shares each) and F. George Heldt and C.B. Power (one share each). These men also served as the Company's Board of Trustees, alternating the offices of the Board among themselves. When McKnight died on January 20, 1903, the other three trustees continued the business until the expiration of the J.H. McKnight Company charter on June 4, 1914. At that time the corporation was dissolved and all company property was sold, with the assets of the firm totaling more than $108,000. This money was dispersed to the corporation's stockholders.

scopecontent.head: Content Description:
scopecontent.p: These records are primarily concerned with the basic daily operation of the McKnight business. The correspondence consists of orders directed to McKnight from soldiers and settlers of the Fort Shaw area and of transactions with various suppliers of the McKnight firm. The financial records consist of bills and statements, both with individuals and with supplying companies, and bound volumes including journals, ledgers, and cash books. The remainder of the material is composed of legal documents (including licenses, agreements, and contracts), and of materials relating to the formal organization of the J.H. McKnight Company, 1894-1914.

arrangement.p: Arranged by series. Some material housed in the manuscript volumes. See inventory below for more information.

userestrict.p: Researchers must use collection in accordance with the policies of the Montana Historical Society. The Society does not necessarily hold copyright to all materials in the collection. In some cases permission for use may require additional authorization from the copyright owners. For more information contact an archivist.

prefercite.p: Item description and date. Collection Title. Collection Number. Box and Folder numbers. Montana Historical Society Research Center, Archives, Helena, Montana.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the Montana Historical Society Archives catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search under these terms.

dsc.head: Detailed Description of the Collection
dsc.p: The following section contains a detailed listing of the materials in the collection

did.unittitle: J.H. McKnight, F. George Heldt, John Heldt
J.H. McKnight & Co., Fort Benton (F. George Heldt) and J.H. McKnight & Co., Great Falls (J.H. McKnight)

A (correspondents include J.C. Adams, American Wine Company, Anheuser-Busch Brewing Association, J. Armitage, Anthony and Kuhn Brewing Company, F.E. Augustin, C.H. Austin, James W. Austin, J.W. Avery)
John E. Blaine; James F. Blaine (Helena)
C.A. Broadwater and Company; Broadwater, McCulluh and Company

B (correspondents include Bach, Cory and Company; Bain Wagon Company; W.C. Bartlett; Frank Bartos; Best, Russell and Company; John Billing; Nathan F. Block; H.D. Blossom; J.V. Bogert; E.L. Bonner and Company; W.J. Boston; C.L. Bristol; George L. Browning; Frank Bull; W.P. Burcher)

C (correspondents include E.W. Carpenter, Marie Carrothers, J.W. Carter, John K. Castner, W.K. Cate, W.C. Child, J. Choate, E. Dalrymple Clark, Horace Clark, Joseph Cobell, Robert Coburn, H.J. Coffroth, Charles E. Colbert, Tom Connolly, William Courtenay)
D (correspondents include J. Damien, David Dannitt [?], Davis and Wallace, T.J. Demers, Detroit and Montana Cattle Company, John Devine, N.C. Draper, J.R. Drew, Thomas Dunn, John C. Duval)
E (correspondents include Eddy, Harvey and Carter; C.F. Ellis and Company, William F. Ensign, W.R. Evans)

F (correspondents include W.F. Fanton, James Fergus, First National Bank of Fort Benton, Fish Brothers Wagon Company, Fisk and Van Uxum, M.A. Flanagan, J.H. Ford, R.S. Ford, Sam Ford, L. Cass Forsyth, Frankel and Block, Fred R. Frost)
G (correspondents include William Gaddis, James Gibson, Paris Gibson, William W. Giddings, W.C. Gillette, S.P. Goin, F.S. Goss, Ike Greenhood)
A.B. Hamilton; Hamilton and Hazlett (Sun River, Choteau)
F.F. Healy; J.J. Healy; William Healy (Sun River)
Joseph Hirshberg and Company (Choteau); Julius Hirshberg and Company (Sun River)
A.M. Holter and Brother; Holter Lumber Company
H (correspondents include R.S. Hale, S.M. Hall, A.C. Haptonstall, Elbert E. Hanchett, Edward Harper, R.B. Harrison, Oliver Hastzal, I.N. Hazlett, D.C. Holbrook, Q. Van Hummell, Ed L. Huntley)
I-J (correspondents include C. Imoda, I.R. Jackson, Joy and Fitzpatrick)
Nick Kessler; Kessler and Miller; Kessler's Brewery (Helena)
K (correspondents include J.A. Kanouse, John Keiplinger, Charles P. Kellogg and Company, F. Kendrick, Fred J. Kiesel and Company, Joseph Kipp, T.S. Kirtland)
John Largent and Company; James M. Largent (Sun River)
L (correspondents include A.L. Langellier, A. Lavenberg, Lawrence and Martin, T.W. Leighton, John Lepley, J.E. Lippincott, Richard Lockey, L. Loomis, P. Lorillard and Company, A.C. Lux)
Mc (correspondents include David McCranor, John McCune, William McLaughlin, Louis S. McLure, J.H. McRae)
F.W. Miller (South Fork Sun River; Helena)
Murphy, Neel and Company (Helena); Murphy, Maclay and Company (Great Falls)

M (correspondents include James Machaud, Mansfield and Stickney, George F. Marsh, Nick Millen, George F. Miller, Miller and Addoms, Miller and Rosencrans, H. Milot, J.H. Ming and Company, John E. Morgan, O.H. Morgan, Morris Brothers, John Murphy, P. Murtha)

N-O (correspondents include August Nagel, E. Nebel, H.H. Nelson, R. Bennington Nevitt, W.E. Norris and Brother, Northern Pacific Railroad, Otto Norton [letterhead includes map of Fort Shaw], J.J. O'Connor)
T.C. Power and Brother; T.C. Power and Company
P (correspondents include Pacific Glove Works, A. Pambrun, A.H. Peaslee, Peoples National Bank, J.L. Perkins, A.K. Prescott, W.G. Preuitt and Company)
Q (correspondents include W.J. Quan and Company, William Quinton, E.S. Quigley)

R (correspondents include Racine Wagon and Carriage Company, J.C. Rainsford, Philip Reade, Reed and Sherwood, W.I. Reed, Rocky Mountain Telegraph Company, Adolph Roenche, H.J. Rosencrans, Charles Rowe, Peter Rush, William Ryan)

S (correspondents include John Salfinger, San Jose Fruit Packing Company, Wilbur Fisk Sanders, J.B. Sanford, Jacob Schmidt, Schwab and Zimmerman, George W. Smith, Spitzly and Sloan, Stewart and Scott, Benjamin Stickney, Mattie Strong, Granville Stuart, J.T. Sullivan, M. Sweetland, Thomas Switzer)
T (correspondents include John B. Taylor, E.J. Thomas, Mrs. R. P. Thoroughman, Robert Tingley, Cris Tillesen, James Travis, John B. Traxler)
U.S. Army (includes memorandum re liquor on army bases)
U.S. Army (Fort Shaw: includes official letters and orders for goods by soldiers)
U.S. Indian Service; Bureau of Indian Affairs (includes Blackfeet Agency)
U (correspondents include William Ulm, Union Republican Congressional Executive Committee, U.S. government agencies)
V (correspondents include Valley Hotel, N. Van Beil, A.R. Van Eman, Peter Van Schaack and Sons, R. Vaughn)
Walter A. Wood Mowing and Reaping Machine Company (Chicago)

W (correspondents include J.C. Walker and Brother, F.F. Walrath, A.C. Warner, George Warner, O.B. Warwick, Webster and Koontz, A. Weisenhorn, Charles K. Wells, Wells Fargo and Company, D.H. Weston, W.S. Wetzel, George Willard, T.E. Williams, John J. Woods, T.G. Woods)
Y (correspondents include M. Yurnell, Otto Young and Company, unidentified)
C-S (correspondents include J.I. Case Threshing Machine Company, John W. Hannay, T.C. Power and Brother, Superior Supply and Fuel Company)
Account book (includes payments received for passenger fares at Sun River Station, 1870?; trial balances, 1869-1871; general journal, 1871; inventory, 1878-1884)
Daybook: Cutter and Taylor (includes warehouse inventory, 1883-1888)
Daybooks: "no. 21" - "no. 22" [remainder of daybooks overlap with one set being Monday-Wednesday-Friday the other being Tuesday-Thursday-Saturday]
Inventory book (includes tax assessment roll for 1878-1888)
Journal: Cutter and Taylor (includes warehouse inventory, March 1886)
"Wagons, Implements, Tent Covers, Building Materials" (includes prices, kinds, weights, etc.)
Board of trustees' meetings, notices, etc.
Freight tariff listing and rules; fabric samples and price lists
